Dear Mrs. Canales:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 2/24/2025 and 2/25/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department
of human services, the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial agency, or equivalent agency

in the country where the person usually resides,
that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The
documentation shall be completed not more than
30 days prior to the start of employment and every
12 months thereafter.
One of thirteen new employee files reviewed did not have the Central Registry
approved within 30 days of hire as the Central Registry was completed over 30
days prior to hire.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was provided to the facility regarding CCI Rule
400.4155(2) and 400.4156(2) to document input from the resident, resident’s
parents, direct care staff, and referral source, unless documented why, on the
initial treatment plan and updated treatment plan as the facility currently is
documenting this information on the facilities Master Treatment Plan in the
goals and objectives section.
• Technical assistance was provided to the facility regarding CCI Rule
400.4155(1)(b) to document plans for parent and child visitation in the initial
treatment plan and updated treatment plan as the facility currently is
documenting this information on the facilities Master Treatment Plan in the
goals and objectives section.
• Technical assistance was provided to the facility regarding CCI Rule
400.4155(3)(h) regarding documenting coordination with the agency assigned
to complete adoption or permanency planning for permanent court wards or
MCI wards in the initial treatment plan and updated treatment plan as the
facility currently is documenting this information on the facilities Master
Treatment Plan in the goals and objectives section.
• Technical assistance provided to the facility regarding documenting attempts
and efforts to locate the permanency planning worker assigned to the youth in
the initial treatment plan if the facility is unable to identify the permanency
worker’s contact information in the first thirty days the youth is at the facility.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Date education verification to show when the facility received the education
verification.
• The agency incorporates overview of the job description in orientation training,
provided consultation for the job description to be signed by the employee
during orientation training.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
• 2024 Interim: Correction Action Plan was recorded during this reporting
period as a result of the Interim Inspection dated 6/4/2024. This CAP
contained rule violations of CCI Rule 400.4113(1)(j) Employee Records
regarding staff evaluations and CCI Rule 400.4114(1) Tuberculosis
screening for employees and volunteers. The facility submitted a CAP
that was approved on 7/23/2024 which contained action steps to ensure
employee evaluations were completed annually as well as tuberculosis
testing prior to hire and documentation of annual tuberculosis screening.
The CAP was successful as there were no repeat violations found
during the Renewal Inspection.
• Special Investigation 2024SIC0001372 with CAP approval date of
9/24/2024 was a result of violations regarding sufficiency of staffing,
Chief Administrator responsibilities, and internal policy not being
followed regarding supervision of youth on suicide precaution. The
agency provided training for staff regarding Emotional Intelligence,
verbal de-escalation training, suicide prevention training, staff reviewing
youth safety plans on a weekly basis, improved communication amongst
staff, support and supervision for the Chief Administrator, and coaching
development for all staff. The agency is currently complying with the
CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with
no noted concerns.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000142 with CAP approval date of
1/16/2025 was a result of violations regarding medication storage and
medication dispensing. The agency updated internal policy, retrained
staff regarding medication storage and medication passing, and has
implemented steps to monitor medication passing and ensuring the
medication closet is properly secured. The agency is currently
complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor
CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and agency's financial audit.

PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. Chief Administrator reported
the agency was able to identify barriers with the leadership team staff, issues with
staff and youth cutler, lack of communication in the program, retention of staff, staff
accountability, and staff not utilizing de-escalation skills and trauma informed care
when working with youth in crisis situations. Through the barriers identified, the
agency implemented correction action plans that made significant improvements
as the agency implemented internal quality improvement plans to increase service
delivery, improve the quality of programming and improved outcomes based on
the agency’s internal quarterly reviews.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews with staff indicated the agency has continued to grow and improve as
several new staff have been employed in the last year. Two staff reported the
agency, and staff are consistent with setting boundaries and expectation with
youth and youth being well cared for. One employee reported new staff need
additional support from upper management as training does not adequately equip
staff for the reality of working with the youth as well as inconsistency with staff
following agency rules.
Youth interviews were conducted during onsite visit. Two youth interviewed
reported feeling safe at the facility. One youth verbalized feeling unsafe at times
due to other youth at the facility. Two youth verbalized the facility has recently
implemented new rules which are not consistently followed by staff. One youth
reported no concerns at the facility.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walk through of the facility occurred on February 24,
2025. The facility was clean and there were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION

Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
